questionsData.title: Car battery contains acetic acid.
When water is heated it changes into solid.
The spoon has two sides, one is convex and the other is concave.
Sound travel as particles not as waves.
Vaccines are very weak forms of disease.
What you see during an eclipse depends on where you are on earth.
Tall and long are synonyms.
The liger is a cross between a lion and a jackal.
Students use tractors to go to school.
Diligent and lazy are synonyms.
Fault line is where two plates meet.
Rescue teams are people who work in factories.
"Slight damage" means "little damage".
Offering and giving are synonyms.
School leavers are people who give advice.
"Yours sincerely" is written at the end of the letter.
Four-wheel drive is a kind of cars.
Blanching is salted liquid.
Puzzles and riddles are synonyms.
Voyage is a kind of ships.
questionsData.explain_answer:
No, that's not quite right.

  • Voyage is a noun that refers to a long journey, especially at sea.
  • Ship is a noun that refers to a large waterborne vessel.

Here's a better way to think about it:

  • A voyage is the journey itself.
  • A ship is the vessel that takes the voyage.

So, a ship can make many voyages throughout its lifetime.

questionsData.title: The text is mainly talking about……………
questionsData.article: Air pollution and global warming as most scientists agree, seems to go hand in hand. The main component of this phenomenon is the greenhouse gas, carbon dioxide. Carbon Dioxide is a (necessary 1) gas for our survival. They call (it 3) a greenhouse gas because it makes the Earth habitable by blocking some of the sun’s radiations from exiting the atmosphere. This is the reason Carbon Dioxide is called a greenhouse gas because this is exactly what happens in a glass house where plants are grown.(Without 2) carbon dioxide, the whole planet would be covered in ice. Just like anything else in life, too much of a good thing can be a problem, and that is what scientists have been warning us for years. Carbone dioxide levels have now risen to 31% of pre-industrial revolution days and the gas emitted from 100 to 200 years ago may still be in our atmosphere today. A constant warming cycle can start melting polar ice caps and causes flooding.

questionsData.title: The film was…….. interesting.
questionsData.explain_answer:
The film was interesting.

"Interesting" is an adjective that describes the film, so it does not require an article before it.

"An" and "a" are indefinite articles, and they are used before a singular, countable noun that is being introduced for the first time.

questionsData.title: One of the following words is a compound word.
You have to up the chair to mop the floor. The word "up" is a/ an………
questionsData.explain_answer: The word "up" in the context of "You have to up the chair to mop the floor" is acting as a verb. It is being used as a transitive verb meaning to lift or raise the chair.

questionsData.title: The suffix ………changes the word "change "into an adjective.
Ahmed is……… than his brother Nasser.
Nora is as… as her friend Sarah.
A nurse looks ……. patients.
The house in …….I used to live, is old.
They like the Yemeni food……..the Lebanese.
Teachers have to be ………
It usually ….. in Jordan in January.
Ameen ……… married next week.
questionsData.explain_answer:
Ameen is getting married next week.

  • "Getting" is the present participle of the verb "get," which is used to form the continuous tense.
  • "Is getting" indicates that Ameen is in the process of becoming married.
  • "Gets" (simple present tense) wouldn't work because it suggests a habitual action, not a specific event like a wedding.
  • "Get" (present tense) is too informal for this context.

Therefore, "is getting" is the most natural and grammatically correct way to express that Ameen is going to be married soon.

questionsData.title: ………. Qat is a bad habit.
After I …… my breakfast, I went to school.
Two cars …….. yesterday.
Yesterday a man …….. for stealing a bank.
I heard a little boy….. in the garden.
It ….. rain tomorrow, there are a lot of clouds.
I always do my homework………
Have the students…….. their books.
questionsData.explain_answer:
Use of have/get + infinitive

You use these verbs to replace other instruction words such as ask, tell or order.

Example:

Ask the boy to put away his bag.
→    Have the boy put away his bag.
→    Get the boy to put away his bag.
Note: With have, the infinitive is without to.
